Armcl, io Levin Griffin, Townsend,  8  AvecyB. Howell. Roan.-ike,  8  Israel Butt, Berkley,  6 . Dick C arter shot and fatally wounded Clarence Hodges, aged 18 years, in H odges home, in Roanoke. It seems that Carter, who hails from W inston, N. C., went to Roanoke with a companion named Shelton. They were going to W est Virginia, but, it is alleged, C arter drank heavily and went ino the room s over a saloon occupied by. Fannie H odges and her son. H e claimed to be a Secret Service agent of the Governm ent, it is said, and un dertook to dislodge the tenants. W il liam M artin grappled with hint in his attempt to shoot young Hodges, but . failed in his effort. The bullet entered the left side of tire neck and evidently lodged about the spinal cord. H is en tire body was paralyzed and his con dition is extrem ely serious, fa rte r at tempted to escape, but was captured and lodged in jail. A trial in Stafford County Court in volving the ownership of a cow afford ed much amuiement to a large crowd of spectators. Joe Baker had been a tenant on the Green Bank farm of M ajor W. S. Ernbrey for 16 years, and was displaced. In turning over the farm property Baker claimed a certain cow as thc property of his wife. M ajor Embrcy was confident thc cow belong ed to him. The case first came up in a m agistrates court, and was removed to thc County C ourt of Stafford, where four lawyers took part in the proceed ings before Judge Chichester. .The case went against Baker, and wasap pealed, and will b e . carried to the cir cuit Court. Mrs. Baker, who claims the cow, though only 43 years old, is thc m other of 17 children. 1.4 of whom arc living and 5 are married. In the Circuit Court at W inchester. S. H. Braithvvaite was given 1200 damages against Charles K. M cllwee for alienation of his wifes affections. Mr. Baithwaite asked for 5000 dam  ages, claiming that M cllwee had not only alienated his wifes affections, but had also caused her to desert him and his five children. All the parties con cerned are prom inent residents of the county. Some sensational evidence was introduced during the trial. G eorge Christian, colored, was elec trocuted at N ew port News by coming in contact with a live wire. H e caught hold of the wire leading to a 16 -candle- power light at a point where the insu lation was worn off. It is thought the feed wire m ust have been crossed witlj a street wire, as death was instantane ous and there was current enough to burn off three fingers. The barn of J. A. Storm , near Lew- insville, Fairfax county, was burned and 14 horses and four cows were burned or lost in the fire. J t is esti mated that the loss will be over  4000 . Panhandle coal operators refuse to accept the scale adopted at thc subdis trict conference and state that they will oppose it to the last. Business men of Crewe have formed a trade organization, with these officers President, Thomas B. O liver first vice- president, C. E. W ilson secretary, B. N. W aterhouse treasurer, Capt. E. F. Loc kett. The Virginia Anthracite Coal Com pany is building a railroad to open up the large area of coal lands iii Mont gomery county. The line will later be extended so as to run from Christian- burg to Blacksburg. George Tinsley, one of five negroes charged with robbing German sailors of the steamship Albano, was given eight years in the penitentiary ait Newport News. The evidence showed that i ins- ley was in the crowd that beat the sail ors. The fact that several German coins lost by one of the sailors were found in his pockets convicted him. Thc Jamestown Exposition advocates in thc House have thc whip-hand, and succeeded in defeating the bill to appro priate an additional  100,000 for the im provement and enlargement of the Capi tol. They also succeeded in having April 2 set as a date for again taking up the Jamestown appropriation. 1 he Mann Prohibition bill was prac tically killed in the Senate Finance Com mittee after being so amended as not to apply to towns of over 1,000 or to sum mer resorts. A business mens league has been formed at Buena Vista with R. W. VVin- borne as president. Anoth i-annery is under construction at the lower end of Arnolds Valley, Rockbridge county, owned by R. McC. Paxton  Bro. and T. Rapp. The contracts have been let for build- ing-at Cape Henry a pavillion which will accommodate 15.000 people and cost  30 , 000 , and also for bathhouses near by. The buildings will he finished in about 60 days. W ork will begin this wreek. Fish -are beginning to run well in the Potomac and Rapnahannock rivers and their tributaries. H erring arc now sell ing for i.Co per hundred, shad 40 cents to 80 cents a pair, perch 15 cents to 50 cents a bunch and rockfish 30 cents to 60 cents a hunch. Sheriff Curtis, of Hamoton. has re ceived information that Emmett Lends, colored, who is wanted in Hampton on the charge of killing George Davidson, is in Cincinnati. Samuel Carey, colored, said to be the oldest man in Virginia, died at his home on M ulberry Island, in W arwick county. Carey leaves several sons, all of whqm have reached an advanced age. H e claimed to be 117 years old. At W illiam sburg the jury acquitted Nancy Thornton, the negro conjur er, who was charged with the m urder of her husband. The m arriage of Miss K atherine Crawley to Mr. Elisha W oodfin M ad ison is announced to take place at Centenary Church, Stoddcrt, on April 1 st.

Dunning, Norfolk. 8 Elizabeth A. Copeland, W est End, 8 M ajor Alexander Quail, of Iowa, anc his bride, who was Mrs. Maggie Rawl mgs, of Spottsylvania, arc now on an ex tended bridal trip North. This marriage occurred a few days ago at the home oi the bride, and the courtship leading ur to it was most romantic. M ajor Quail while in Fredericksburg last year, save the photograph of Mrs. Rawlings, anc when lie returned home he wrote to her rhis led to a correspondence, which cul minated in their marriage at their first meeting. M ajor Quail is a man of con siderablc means and his bride is an ac complished lady. They will for the pres ent reside at Spottsylvania Courthouse A son a i Mr. Edgar Goodrick, oi Fredericksburgv had his leg broken anc his foot badly mashed by being caught ir. a pile of rolling railroad ties on which he was sitting. Former Mayor Davis Edmondson Mrs. Lucy Maltestcr and Albert Rhodes of Middletown, were held on it addi tional indictments, charging arson anc robbery, by a special grand jury in the County Court. Edmondson and photic are under indictment for burning Ed mondsons property to secure the insur ance. These latest indictments charge that Edmondson, through revenge, hirec Rhodes to burn other valuable husinesi property after robbing it. and that the Maltester woman acted as their fence. Both houses of the Virginia Legisla ture agreed on a bill to prevent chile labor in factories and it was sent to the Governor for his signature, which wili make it a law of the State. The bill at agreed upon is practically the Lyle bill, the House receding from its principal amendments. It provides that no chilei under 12 years of age shall be employee in factories in this State and regulate the hours of work for children under 1 1 years. An official statement was made thal the T. C. Williams Tobacco Company of Richmond is to be sole! to the British American Tobacco Company and thal the deal is about to be closed. The W il liams Company has an enormous forcigr trade, enjoying almost a monopoly ir. Australia, and it was for this reason tha the trust was so anxious to acquire it. The four Belgian sailors from the British steamship St. George, arrested a Newport News on the charge of smug giing tobacco ashore, were released bj United States Commissioner Garret. The Commissioner did not think the tobaccc would have been brought ashore but fo  solicitation, on the part of the ge-bc tween, who already had arranged for the capture of the alleged smugglers. A lex Johnson, colored, was drownee in the Rappahannock river, near P or Royal. He was out in a skiff, which war upset by the high winds, and though ai expert swimmer, did not succeed ir reaching the shore. The National Elks Home at Bcdforc City will be dedicated on M ay 21. The orator for the occasion will be Meade D Detwellcr, of Harrisburg, Pa. Addresses will lie made by Senator Daniel and Governor Montague. By the collapse of a floor overloaded with brick four workmen On the Frs National Bank building at Harrisburg, were precipitated from the third story tc the ground. A white man named John Long was killed. French Turner, col ored, received injuries from which ht cannot recover and two colored boy? were badly hurt. Ihe Petersburg Chamber of Com merce and the Young Mens Business Association were consolidated under the name of the Petersburg Chamber oi Commerce. Simon Seward was elected president. Miss Ida Briscoe, a young girl about 16 years of age, was killed by the acci dental discharge of a shotgun neat Abingdon. The trouble between Parkersburg and the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Com pany has been compromised. The city grants the railroad the right to lay track for a few feet on Avery street, and th railroad promises to lay no more track. there without 30 dav notice. Members of the Virginia Legislature arc to play bail in Richmond for the benefit of the Confederate Bazar. Clifton Maynard was arraigned in 1 Richmond court, charged with stealing diamond rings from a jeweler. Aftei changing his name in the indictment tc Manor he pleaded guilty and was sent tc the reformatory. George Blaine, who was shot in Staun ton by a Chesapeake and Ohio con ductor, is wanted by Roanoke authori ties, charged with killing a conductor o the Norfolk and Western, near Roanoke Blaine is in the Staunton jail. The large barn and its contents on th farm of Tinsley H. Twyman, of Spott sylvania county, was destroyed bv fire High winds were destructive to fishing property along the Potomac river. It Potomac creek a large skiff , was cap sized and sunk, three fishermen having a narrow escape from drowning. An increase of wages has been grantee to boiler-makers of the Norfolk anc Western Railroad

Following the indoctrination Rhett Mozingo, Wood Procure ment Manager. Tom Marshall, Assistant Wood Procurement Manager and Woodyard Mana ger, and their team of Foresters - Mike Gibbs, Blair Meredith, Marvin Tinsley and Jim Wood - hosted the group at a barbecue on the mill grounds. With start-up so close at hand, the event was most timely. Once in production, the mill will require some 3,500 cords of pulpwood per week. This continuous need will provide hundreds of loggers in the area with a dependable market for their harvest - a fact that both Virginia Fibre and the wood producers appreciate.

document.text: Thelma, the five-year-old daughter of Nickolas Ferrell, of Lamberts Point, who was badly bitten by a dog, is the object of great anxiety. Her face was so lacerated that six stitches were re quired to close the wounds and one of her teeth was forced out. The dog was lolled and its head sent to the Pasteur Institute to ascertain if the animal was mad. While the dredge of the Atlantic Dredging Company was dredging the Ap- pamattox River at Petersburg it brought up a live turtle, the largest ever seen in that section. It measured 28 inches wide and 40 inches long and took two men to take it off the cutter head of the dredge. Alfred Gastons, a well-known negro of Westmoreland County, while digging a well, near Hague, was killed by the cav ing in of the sides of the well. He was suffocated. It was announced at Lynchburg that J. C. Paxton, a lime manufacturer, of Woodstock, had given 5,000 for the pur pose of erecting a new cottage at the Presbyterian Orphanage, which is located near Lynchburg. - The members of the Lynchburg bar tel egraphed Judge Beverly Crump an ex pression of their confidence in his per sonal and official integrity, and express ing themselves as believing he is still thoroughly competent in all respects to remain as a member of the State Corpor ation Commission, despite the censure placed upon him by the investigating committee of the Legislature. The pa per was circulated by J. Tinsley Coleman, Who was associated with the defense of J. Samuel McCue, who was hanged at Charlotteesville. It was signed my many attorneys. Henry Campbell, a traveling salesman, whose home was at Middlesboro, Ky., was found dead in his room at the John son Hotel, at Pennington Gap. By his side was an empty laudanum bottle. The annual meeting of the stockholders of the South Atlantic Life Insurance Company, of Richmond, was held in the Mutual Building. The reports showed a fine financial condition. Edmund Strud- wick was reelected president. Several offers to buy the company have been rejected and the South Atlantic Life will continue on an independent basis as a home company. Judge R. Carter Scott, of the Circuit Court of Henrico, has not yet made an appointment to fill the vacancy created by the death of County Treasurer Todd. Among those being mentioned by their friends for the treasurership are Deputy Treasurer, H. C. Hechler, T. Walker Jeter, a deputy of the former treasurer, Mr. Brauer, and T. J. Todd, the late treasurersson. The treasurers office is closed pending the appointment. With the back of his head seamed by deep gashes and his face bruised and beaten into pulp, the body of a negro about 60 years old was found on the Chesapeake and Ohio viaduct in Fulton, lying face down between the rails. Cor oner Taylor held an inquest. The man is supposed to be H. Martin Diggs, of Lo cust Creek, Louisa County. It is thought he fell from a train. Ulysses Hottel, employed by the South ern Railway as a coal-passer at Stras- burg Junction, suddenly became a raving maniac in a coal bin. He is thought to be hopelessly insane. He keeps at work constantly shoveling coal and shouting that he is getting rich. The efforts of railroaders to quiet him have been in vain. His home is in Woodstock. If was announced from the general offices of the Jamestown Exposition Company that a tower exceeding in alti tude the celebrated Eifel Tower at Paris will in all probability, be erected on the Exposition grounds. A cablegram has been sent to London for plans and speci fications. The -tower would carry up ward of 10,000 incandescent lights and could be seen for miles at sea at night. The brother of C. H. Riggins, who died in the jail at Norfolk, purposes to sue fhe city for the neglect of his broth ers welfare. Riggins was arrested and sentenced to jail for 30 days for steal ing a ham. He was addicted to the mor phine habit, and the contention of his brother is that he was under the influ ence of morphine and that he had no intention of stealing. The autopsy show ed that he died as thc result of organic disease of the liver. Mrs. Mary Augustus Allen, formerly Miss Ironmonger, of Portsmouth, filed a suit at Norfolk, asking for a divorce from her husband, Dr. M. R. Allen, a homeopathic physician. Mrs. Allen ap plies for a limited divorce, alleging cruel ty, failure to provide and many other things. She demands alimony, her attor neys fees and 3,000 in money loaned before and since the marriage. The marriage occurred in Brooklyn, N. Y., May 12, 1904. There are no children. After being out for about two i.ours, the jury in the case of John Gerkin, at Newport News, charged with killing Walter Felton, brought in the verdict of not guilty. The case was taken up in the Corporation Court and the jury ren dered its verdict about 7.40 oclock P. M. The evidence in the case showed that Gerkin was employed as Feltons helper in the plant of the Citizens Electric Company. The men quarreled over some work. Felton struck Gerkin and Gerkin, drove a screw driver through Feltons head. Gerkin is only 17 years old.1 John L. Lee, of Lynchburg, associated, with R. M. Lee for the defence, made a powerful plea for the prisoner,. causing jurors and spectators to shed tears. The prisoners mother and f-ther came from North Carolina and were in the courtroom during the trial.

document.text: The wedding of Miss Sherry Lynn Roope -to Mr. Lewis Leon Paulk, Jr. took place on the afternoon of May 28 at 2 p.m. on the lawn at the home of Mrs. Eliazabeth Harrison. The Reverend Douglas Randlett, youth pastor of Thomas Baptist Church was officiating minister. A program of music was presented by Mr. Lowell Freemire with recordings by Daniel Stratton, pianist. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Dean Roope of Concord and the bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paulk, Sr. of Columbus, Ohio. The bride, given in marriage by her parents, wore a gown of taffeta and net etched in lace, with a fitted bodice, accordin pleats. The front of the skirt flowed back into a chapel train. Her headpiece of net was accented with seed pearls and lace. She carried a bouquet of white rose birds with ivy. streamers and lilac and white lace trows. Miss Cheryl Dawn Davis of Appomattox was maid of honor. Sue wore a gown of lilac taffeta and lace and carried a rattan fan with wild lilac flowers. Christina Goodlin of Lynchburg, friend of the bride, was flower girl. She wore a lavender check ginghain dress with white pinafore and bloomers. Scott Tinsley of Amherst, cousin

Our special Washington cor respondent says of him The death of Flood is directly due to his fine devotion to his State and partv When tbs Republicans gave it out that they were going to break into the solid South and that Vir ginia was to be the gateway, everyone knew that it meant another loosening of the strings of the long purse that poured out millions and millions for the election of Harrison, Me Kinley, Roosevelt, Taft and Hardingthe long purse of privilege. The Virginia leaders looked over the field and could see no one but Flood to lea the fight to prevent the Repub licans again getting a foothold in the State that was still re- membring painfully the days of the carpet baggers So Flood wae drafted for the iob, though already Chairman of the Demo cratic Congressional Commit tee, he went into it like he went into every other fight with every ounce of force there was in him Of course he wod , aud the Democrats carried Vir ginia by the biggest majority ever known, but Flood came back to Washington and took to hi bed, never to leave it. Of him it can be truly said  He died with the harness on, the broad sword leaping, the wild fight surging fast  Rich as the party is in leadership, Democracy can ill spare him, this proud Virginian, proud of his clean hands, his clean pub tic record, Lis clean profession al career and his spotless personal character. It is re membered of bim that when he first came t j Congress, defeat ing Jacob Yost, a Republican, the result was very close ano he was offered the certificate of election on. a technicality, wbereu ton be refused to accept it, preferring to stand aside until the status of every ques cioned ba lot wae determined, be knew he might lose by so doing, but be preferred it that way. The folio wiug tribute paid our distinguished countyman by a life-long friend is worthy of both men Nobody seems to be able to realize chat Hal Flood, of Ap pomattox, is dead. We cannot grasp the fact that the mao of vigor and force and activity upon wuern we Had learned to rely, and under whose devoted watch care we had learned to feel secure has been suddenly called from his earthly duties, ank that our friend is no more. Mr. Floods great abilities and worth in public life were uaiversaly recognized. But to the people of Appomattox nr was held in esteem as nowhere else, because it was here that tiis worth in private life was best known. Many years

document.text: Policeman James P. Hsll was held by the mayor in C00 security at Alexandria for the action of tbe grand jury to answer a charge of assaulting William Blight with intent to kill. Bright is about eighteen years of age. Ho ran away from the policeman on tbe river front near Reeds icehouse, and UaH shot him in tho right side, Inflicting wbat is feared may prove to be a mortal wound. The jury could not agree upon a verdict In tbs Nelson murder trial at Charlottesville, and the court adjourned. Judge George H. Harrison, a member of the Buprome Court of Appeals of Virgin a, met with a distressing accident at his resi dence In Staunton, la attempting to move an upright piano about tbe drawing-room the Instrument toppled over and fell on Judge Harrisons right leg, breaking tbe larger bone and fracturing the smaller bone below the knee in two places. Tbe frac tures were reduced by Doctors A. M. and H. Henkel. Alexander Lushbaugb, aged 39 years, died In Staunton as tbe result of a singular Injury received tho Monday previous, and at that time considered of a trifling nature. Eok, as he was popularly known, was en gaged In lath work at the Bodley Works, when bis chisel point struck a knot in the rapidly revolving wood, and Luehbaugh re ceived quite a blow In the abdomen, though there was no cub So little was thought of tbe blow that Lushbnugh continued his work. Perlton tee ensued and caused his death. He was a fear ess volunteer fireman, and last summer when small-pox appeared In Btaunton he rondered courageous and valuable service In guarding and nursing patients. The body of an unknown woman supposed to have Been A passenger on the Old Domin ion steamer Wyaneke when that vossel was sunk off Newport News, was ashore on the beach at that place. Her name Is not known. The bodies of three other persons, supposed to have been passengers on tbe Wyanoke, are said to have come ashore on the Isle ol Wight beach, but the Old Dominion people have not as yet received any information concerning them. No definite steps have been taken as yet to raise the Wyanoke, and she still remains where she went down. Mr. 8. F. Saey, of Columbia, Fluvanna county, was robbed In Richmond of 465 while traversing tho streets. He had tbe money in a valise, and when he got to the bank, whero he was to take up a note,, the money was miss ng. Col. George W. F. Vernon, of Baltimore, bos been invited by George D. Summers Po-t O. A. R., to deliver th e memorial ad dress at Berkeley Springs on Decoration Day. Some of the members of this post were comrades of Colonel Vernon during the war. Prof. Randolph W. Tinsley, son of Mrs. C. C. XI nsley, of Charlottesville, has been elected to the chair of nutural sciences, in the University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, N. M. He to a graduate of the University of Virginia. Rappahannock county is rapidly becoming one of the lead ng apple counties of the State. Many thousands trees have been planted out this season with more to follow. George Whito, of Fauqulr county, cut down a bee tce several days ago from which ho took a barrel of honey and four young coons. A bill baa passed both houses of Congress providing for semi-annual sessions of tbe United States Court at Roanoke. Eugene McNerhauey was run over and killed on the Southern Railway, in Fairfax county, last week. Five Swiss gent emen have recently pur chased farms in Bedf rd county. J. Preston Ware, section master of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad at Maysviiie, Ky., mot with a terriblo and fatal accident at Sml hs Creek, west of Staunton. In at tempting to board the passenger train No. 1 he fell between the wheels and, with skull crushed and both legs eut off he died in half an hour at Clifton Forge The decease was la the Clift .n Forge section looking into bis real estate interest there. He was a Mason

document.text: over 95 pounds. An educational approach to I weight loss is used by the I Conway Diet Institute to teach I its clients how to take weight  off fast and keep it off. The  1,000 calorie a day diet, j reinforced with weekly meet- I ifiga, provide rapid weight loss.  Now nine years old, the 1 Institute conducts 700 weekly meeting in 22 states. Topics for the meetings, I which-encourage member par ticipation, include nutritious I dieting, emotional conditioning, I health and longevity, the I profile of ah overweight person, behavior m odification, and I will-powerdesire. The groups I discuss cause of overweight, I attitudes toward food, home I environment, anxietyovereat- I ing, mid responses to challenge I and success. The diet itself is a 1,000 I calorie, highly nutritious and I satisfying program which ex-  ceeds all the daily nutritional requirements established by I the .AM A. It consists of three I well-balanced meals a day plus I snacks. The Institute publishes its  own cookbook, Appetizing I Slenderizing Recipes, which is I filled with delicious recipes and I food preparation hints. After members have reached I their ideal weight, they are I taught how to reintroduce into I their daily eating patterns, in I moderate amounts, the fatten- I ing foods they have given up. I The program promises perma- I nent slimness if the members I use the knowledge, insight and I motivation that they have   developed at seminars. Headquarted in Columbus, Ohio, the Institute had its beginnings in Virginia in January, 1977. Betty Tinsley of Darlington Heights is lecturer for the Appomattox class. Mrs. Tinsley attended Longwood College and was employed by the Foreign Mission Board of the Southern Baptist Conven tion in Richmond. She later worked in the shipping office of Appom attox Garment Com pany, and is now employed solely by Conway. Further informaiton may be procured by contacting Mrs. Tinsley at 24841771. The brides mother wore a street length dress of navy and white with a corsage of white rosebuds and babys breath. The mother of the groom wore a street length dress of cream Color with a corsage of white rosebuds and babys breath. Also attending the wedding were Miss Debra Paulk of Columbus, Ohio, sister of the bridegroom and Mr. and Mrs. Stoart of Texas, grandparents of the bridegroom. Immediately following the wed ding, the parents of the bride were hosts for a reception at their home. Helping them serve their guests were Mrs. Louise W right of Lynchburg and Mrs. Katherine Cashmore of Waukegan, Illinois, aunts of the bride and Mrs. Delores Tinsley of Amherst, and Mrs. Joyce Ray of Madison. Heights, cousins of the bride. The bride is a graduate of Appomattox County High School and will be employed by a florist in Columbus, Ohio. The bridegroom was graduated from Northside Christian School and is an employee of C P P Security in Columbus. The couple will make their home in Columbus.

document.text: N. Garrette, of Concord, t o o k place Saturday, December 19, at 4 oclock at Hebron Baptist Church in Appomattox. The Rev. John P. Leitner per formed the double ring cere mony. A program of wedding music was provided by Mrs. V. Howard Ford, organist, and Mrs. David Goode, soloist. Given in marriage by her fath er, the bride wore a gown of silk organza and net over taffeta designed with long sleeves and a princess bodice accented with appliques of alencon lace em broidered wih seed pearls. The rounded skirt ending in a chapel train featured an obi sash also appliqued with lace and em broidered with seed pearls. The brides fingertip veil of illusion fell from a crown of seed pearls and sequins, and she carried a bridal bouquet of seasonal flow ers centered with a white orchid. Mrs. Robert E. McClenny, Jr., of Danville, was her sisters ma tron of honor. Bridesmaids were Mrs. Lyle N. Garrette, Jr., of Covington. Miss Carsonette Gar rette, sistfer of the bridegroom, and Miss Dawn Tinsley, of For est. Mr. Garrette was his sons best man. Ushers were William D. Carson, of Parksley, brother of the bride Lyle N. Garrette, Jr., of Covington, brother of the bridegroom Harry T. Coyner, of Waynesboro, Daniel E. Carson, of Appomattox, cousin of the bride and Edward L._Busic,,of Hornaker. After the ceremony, the brides parents entertained with a re ception in the social hall of the church. The bride is a graduate of Vir ginia Baptist Hospital School of Nursing. The bridegroom is a senior at Virginia Polytechnic Institute. After a southern wedding trip, the couple will make their home in Blacksburg.

document.text: J. B. Gray contracted to sell his es tate, Travelers Rest, in Stafford county, to the wife of Dr. O. D. Nor ton, surgeon in the United States Navy, for 23,000. Mrs. Norton has paid only 500. She has made repairs, to the residence, -but it is understood that she now declines to take the property. Mr. Gray has entered suit here for 10,000 damages and has levied on valuable furniture Mrs. Nor ton has stored. In the Circuit Court of Charles County Judge Thomas W. Harrison sentenced Joseph H. Copenhaver for 12 years in the Virginia Penitentiary. Copenhavers attornies, Marshall Mc Cormick and Blackburn Smith, se cured a stay of sentence for 90 days and will take the case to the State Supreme Court. Copenhaver shot and killed his wife last April while on a spree.  He had been confined in the  insane asylum at Staunton on several occasions.  J. Lewis Evans, one of the oldest locomotive engineers in the world, died in Lynchburg, in the seventy- ninth year of his age. He had been in the employ of the Southern and the older companies for over half a cen tury, and for 40 years was engineer on passenger trains, having operated the first train on the old Grange and Al exandria Railroad. He had lived in Lynchburg about 40 years, but during the past year had been very feeble. Mrs. Catherine A. Brady, widow of the late John L. Brady, of Scotttsville, Albemarle county, died at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Robert A. Sanders, at New Baltimore in her ninety-first year. As the result of a row at Buena Vista, Stuart Farrow, a resident of thatt city, had his legs cut off by a freight train, and Edward Tinsley is now confined in the jail at Lexington for shooting Robert White. The lat ter are negroes and quarreled ovet liquor. Farrow was watching the fight and did not notice the approach of the train. He is not expected to live. Mrs. Jane B. Meade, widow of Rich ard Kidder Meade, died .t her home, hear White Post, Clarke county, aged 86 years. She was a daughter o Benjamin Grymes, of Somerset, King George county. A large mortgage is now being spread upon the records of the Cir cuit Court of Warren County. II is  deed of trust by the Norfolk and Western Railroad Company to se cure the sum of 35,000,000. The in strument, which is in book form, bears the date of July 1, 1904, and contains 79 pages of closely printed matter. The State tax amounts to 20,964, and the document has to be recorded in every county through which this railway passes. The trustee is the Guaranty Trust Company of New York. The attempt to wreck a freight tram on the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway near Lynchburg evidently wai planned by four men whose purpose was robbery. One of the men was on the train when it struck the obstruc tion,. and when it stopped he began throwing mOrohandise from, a car. The attempt to loot the train, how ever, was unsuccessful. Roy Christie, 14 years old, of New port News, was thrown from a bicy cle and had his skull fractured from ear to ear. He was removed to the hospital and an operation was per formed, but the physicians entertfiin little hope for his recovery. The boy was speeding along the street on his way from school, when his wheel struck a rock. In the Police Court, at Lynchburg Mayor Smith acquitted E. E. Lips comb, an expressman, of the charge of feloniously shooting Pullman Con ductor Charles L. Harrison in that city two weeks ago, the evidence showing that the shooting was ar accident. A fine 25 was imposed on Lipscomb form criminal carelessness in handling a loaded weapon. The case will be appealed. The-Lynchburg City Council adopt ed a resolution in joint session author izing the City Attorney to take steps to stop the pollution of the James river by pulp mills. It is believed thal this is the beginning of a big fight to be made against pulp mill owners in the vicinity of Covington. Recent ly the water has become black. Mrs. William Corcoran Eustis, of Oatlands, has donated to Leesburg the free services of a professional nurse in memory of her sister, Miss Morton, daughter of ex-Vice Pres ident Levi P. Morton, of New York, who died recently in Paris from ap pendicitis. Walter S. Johnson, of New York, has sold his minority of 3,500 share in the Norfolk and Southern Rail road, and Albert H. Flint, of New York, president of tthe Chesapeake Transit Company, is in control of the two properties. The merger of the roads was determined months ago, but was stopped on the application of the minority stockholders by an injunc tion from Judge Greenbaum, of New York. The price was less than 400,- 300 , but the names of the purchasers are withheld by the attorney who made the transfer in New York. This sale confirms the merger of the two roads and assures the value of the Chesapeake Line to Cape Henry by he profits of the Norfolk and South- rn. Benjamin F. Levy, 20 years of age, af Norfolk, was sent to fail for beat ing his mother, 60 years of age, after 1 quarrel about a rifle the boy wished to take. The third annual exhibition of the Lynchburg Horse Show Association, o be held at Lynchburg on October 11, 12, 13 and 14, promises to be one of the most successful events of its haracter ever attempted in the State of Virginia. Work was commenced on the instal lation of a police patrol system in Lynchburg.

document.text: Eldridge W. Allen, Sr. Eldridge William Allen Sr., 35, of Spout Spring died at 825 a.m. Monday in Lynchburg General Hospi tal. His wife is Yvonne Bartley Allen. t Born in Amherst County, he was a son of Mrs. Roxie Allen Brown of Madison Heights and the late Eldridge B. Allen. He was a member of Spout Spring Baptist Church, a construc tion superintendent and a lay Baptist preacher1. He was a Vietnam veteran and received a bronze Star with V Device for Valor. In addition to his wife and mother, he is survived by his stepfather, Willie E. Br own of Madison Heights three sons, Eldridge Bud- o dy Allen Jr., Dale Patrick Allen and Gregory Scott Allen, all of Spout Spring a daughter, Jennifer Marie Allen of Spout Spring his paternal grandmother, Mrs. W. S. Birdie Allen of Amherst six brothers, Dr. Raymond F. Allen of ., Blacksburg, Robert L. Allen of Lynchburg, Edward W. Allen of Monroe, Kenneth E. Allen of Centreville, Henry  L. Allen and Joe W. Allen, both of Madison Heights two sisters, Mrs. W. Tinsley Roxie Apn Hill of Amherst and Mrs.Donny R. Bettie Sue Jennings of Madison Heights.      Funeral services were held at -11 a.m. Wednesday V in  Spout .Spring Baptist Church by the Rev. George Kreidel, Sr. and, Dr. Ray mond Allen. Burial was in the church cemetery. Robinson Funeral Home was in charge of arrange ments.

document.text: Collision With Podoifrlan Rostoros Votorans Momory  WICHITA, KAN.Collision of two pedestrians on a street brought back the memory of one suffering from amnesia. Calvin W. Tinsley. 98, a navy vet eran of Davenport, Iowa, rushed into police headquarters to ask wmere he was. H learned he was 700 miles from home. Tinsley told police the last thing he remembered was leaving his job with a construction company at Rock Island, 111., near Davenport. Searching hie pockets, the youth found a list of unbought groceries, 24 cents in change and an empty billfold. Tinsleys wife and parents tele phoned that they were coming here for him. He had been missing four days. The disappearance had not been ra ported to Davenport police.

document.text: BETTY JUSTICE TAKES OFF POUNDS! The Conway Diet Institute has been in operation in Appomattox since January of 1977. Many local people are successfully taking weight off in the Monday night meetings, one of whom is Mrs. Betty Justice of Appomattox, shown above, who recently received her 20-pound achievement pin. The 20-pound mark is the first major goal we try to reach at the Conway Diet Institute, says Betty Tinsley, lecturer for the Appomattox Club. After reaching a 20-pound loss the dieter feels a new self assurance and more positive self-image. This enables him to be more confident and successfully reach his total goal. Mrs. Justice is doing a beautiful job of taking off her excess pounds and I feel that she will emerge as a real winner in our weight reduction program, says Mrs. Tinsley, j Area meetings are held- on Mondays-at 730 p.m. in the Fidelity American Bank, HUlcrest Branch on Moses Street. Anyone interested may contact Betty Tinsley at 248-6771 for more information.

document.text: BECKHAM, May 25.-Mrs. H. R. Moore has been sick for several days, hut is reported better at this writing. T. Burge Moore, of Oakville spent a few days last week fish ing with his brother, C. A. Moore, on James river. Mr. and Mrs. C. A. Mopre were gladly surprised Sunday by having all their children, grandchildren, and in-laws present for the day. W. R. Tinsley, of Roanoke, was a visitor in this neighbor hood the past week. The Epworth League of the two churches, Mt. Comfort and Trinity, are expecting to meet Wednesday afternoon on the James for a fish fry. ------------ o ----------- - Notice

document.text: At present State Senator Moses represents the Eleventh Senatorial District, composed of the counties of Appomattox, Charlotte, Bucking ham and Cumberland. The new pro posal would do away with this dis trict and put Appomattox and Buck ingham in with Amherst and Nelson counties in the Fourth Senatorial District, tag Cumberland on to the Ninth District, now represented by Senator Robert K. Brock, and tag Charlotte on to Halifax. That woulq leave Senator Moses and Senator I, Paul Wailes, of Amherst and Nel son in the same district, and one would have to be eliminated. In the proposal for Tediatrlcting the House of Delegates,. John B. Boatwright, who now represents Ap pomattox and Buckingham, woukl be blitzed by a similar maneuver. . Appomattox county would be put in with Amherst county which is twice its size and Buckingham co unty would be put in with Nelson county, now represented by Delegate J. Tinsley Coleman. IThe approximate 1940 population of these counties follows Appomattox, 9,012 Buckingham, 13,389 Amherst 19,020 Nelson, 16,241. Ibis proposal is only tentative. A public hearing on it will be held at the State Capital March 17, at 11 A. M. The Commission is headed by State Senator E. R. Fuller, of Richmond. Even if the proposal re mained unchanged by the Commis sion, it would have to run the gauntlet of passing the next session of the General Assembly, and not be effective until 1943 elections. The object of the reshuffling is to provide additional representation for sections of Virginia which have had extraordinary increases in pop ulation in recent years.
